intro: Wigginsia corynodes, commonly known as the coastal wigginsia, is a flowering plant native to the coastal regions of southern California and northern Baja California. It is a member of the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen shrub form. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically pink or white, blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are leathery and dark green, adapted to withstand the salty air and strong winds of its coastal habitat. Wigginsia corynodes plays an important ecological role in stabilizing sandy soils and providing habitat for native wildlife.
